etymology.description: 乂(乂) (yì, "to govern/cut") was originally used for its sound -> 刈(刈) (yì, "to cut") displaced 乂(乂) -> a stroke was added on top of 乂(乂) to distinguish it for the meaning of righteousness -> final form 义(義)
etymology.interpretation: Originally, 乂(乂) was used for both its phonetic and semantic meanings but was mainly displaced by 刈(刈). To distinguish the idea of "righteousness," a stroke was added, creating a differentiation that allowed the character to develop its own unique meaning related to justice and propriety.

examples.chinese: 他行侠仗义(他行俠仗義)，扶危济困(扶危濟困)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xíng xiá zhàng yì, fú wēi jì kùn.
examples.english: He upholds chivalry and helps those in distress.

examples.chinese: 他始终坚守义(他始終堅守義)，维护公正(維護公正)。
examples.pinyin: Tā shǐ zhōng jiān shǒu yì, wèi hù gōng zhèng.
examples.english: He always adheres to righteousness and upholds fairness.
